clinical_study.brief_title: Sucralfate to Improve Oral Intake in Children With Infectious Oral Ulcers: a Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial
clinical_study.official_title: Sucralfate to Improve Oral Intake in Children With Infectious Oral Ulcers: a Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to see if sucralfate, a medication commonly used for patients with stomach ulcers, may help pediatric patients with mouth ulcers decrease their pain level and improve their ability to drink.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age ≥6 months and ≤5 years old
- Present with oral infectious ulcers such as gingivostomatitis, herpangina, or hand, foot and mouth disease
- History of decreased oral fluid intake by parent or guardian
- English or Spanish speaking parents or guardians
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severely dehydrated or toxic, requiring immediate resuscitation
- Exclusively breastfed
- Severe dental disease
- Significant mouth trauma
- Active Malignancy
- Preexisting upper airway obstruction or swallowing difficulties
- Received intravenous fluids within 24 hours
- Administration of BOTH acetaminophen AND ibuprofen prior to triage and within 4 hours of enrollment
